instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead brain
threads.message:
This one is cycling once and then stay on is that normal?
All rails present Vcore is at 1,7V, no reactions, no light when mouse is plugged...

History, no water damage, absolutely clean, customer say he felt laptop a little hot so he changed the thermal paste and he sprayed air can when it was off (maybe we should hear ON). Then the board stopped booting.

I don't want to spend time as I did on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Will giva a bios try and the end.

any ideas?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead brain
threads.message: I tried another bios and nothing change...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead brain
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL>?
Check if any resistor, or cap is not ripped off near the heatsink screws...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A dead brain
threads.message: Yes both of them are 3.3v present...:confused:
